title: Ellen awards high school class full college scholarships
text:
An entire class of seniors at a New York high school received the shock of a lifetime while being featured on Ellen Degeneres' talk show.
The class of 2017 at Summit Academy in Red Hook, Brooklyn were told on Thursday that in collaboration with Walmart, all of them would receive a full scholarship to any state university in New York for a four-year course.
The comedian and host is known for her philanthropic acts, but as she noted - this is the biggest gift the show has ever given, worth $1.6million.
Tears streamed down the student and teacher's faces as they screamed with excitement at the news.
The founder and principal at the school, Natasha Campbell and Cheryl Swift, were brought on to the show a few weeks ago where Ellen awarded them $25,000 for their diligent educational work.
Campbell said: 'We are in the Red Hook section, and it's one of Brooklyn's most under-served communities.
'Four per cent of the adults have obtained a college degree, or gone to college.
'Over 28 per cent of the children under 16 live in poverty.'
The founder and principal at the school, Natasha Campbell, left, and Cheryl Swift, right, were brought on to the show a few weeks ago where Ellen awarded them $25,000 for their diligent educational work
Summit Academy, however, plans to change that record - and boasts 97% of their first graduating class currently enrolled in college.
Their goal for 2017 was to have 100% of the graduating class move on to higher education.
Ellen then invited the women back to her show on Thursday, and invited the senior class at Summit Academy to accompany them.
A few of the children had the opportunity to come down to the main stage and speak with Ellen about the impact that the school has had on them.
One young woman said: 'For me it totally turned around my whole life.
'I feel confident and I really feel like I can do something with my life and be a role model for my younger siblings who look up to me.
She went on to discuss how she would be the first person in her family to go to college.
'I'm next, I'm not going to be a disappointment. I'm going to be somebody.'
The comedian and host is known for her philanthropic acts, but as she noted - this is the biggest gift the show has ever given, worth $1.6million
As the show wrapped up, Ellen brought the entire class on stage to accompany her, and she asked the administrators what it meant to them to be able to motivate these children who come from extreme hardships.
Ellen said: 'It's important for all of us to hear this story because a lot of us - we take advantage of how easy our life is, and to go to the school we want to go to, and to do the easiest things.
'These kids have overcome all kinds of things and they go to school every single day and they work hard every single day - and all they want to do is go to college, and they deserve that.'
The heartfelt moment brought tears to Ellen's eyes as she closed the show, asking of her audience to 'be kind to one another'
She then announced that Walmart had decided to fund all of their education for the next four years.
The group erupted with joy and hugged the comedienne, thanking her profusely as a banner unfurled.
The heartfelt moment brought tears to Ellen's eyes as she closed the show, asking of her audience to 'be kind to one another'.
